bug.author: bdarsh
bug.description:
Describe the bug When I tried to decrypt the encoded string with Ciphey, it will try to crack it and in the end, it is unable to crack it and I got the output saying "Failed to crack". To Reproduce Steps to reproduce the behavior:
What input did you use? Ans. I'm trying to decode the string "Ecgudfxq_EcGmP". This is the input: "Ecgudfxq_EcGmP" What flags / arguments did you use? Ans. I used the "-t" flag/argument. So this is the input command: ciphey -t "Ecgudfxq_EcGmP"
After running Ciphey with and the result is here in this file: <denchmark-link:https://github.com/Ciphey/Ciphey/files/5121058/trace.log>trace.log</denchmark-link>
Expected behavior The encoded strings seem to be encoded using the substitution type (caesar)cipher, probably ROT14. So, Ciphey should easily decode it and we should have got the plain text back. But It was failed to crack the encoded string.
<denchmark-link:https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/70128281/91116291-06938e00-e65a-11ea-8f55-277a2ba7d979.png></denchmark-link>
Versions:
OS/Distro: Kali Linux 2020.2 Python version: Python 3.8.3 Ciphey versions: Name: ciphey Version: 5.2.0 Summary: Automated Decryption Tool Home-page: None Author: Brandon Author-email: brandon@skerritt.blog License: MIT Location: /home/USER/.local/lib/python3.8/site-packages Requires: flake8, yaspin, cipheydists, appdirs, base58, pylint, pyyaml, click, click-spinner, cipheycore, loguru, pybase62, rich Required-by: Name: cipheycore Version: 0.2.9 Summary: Home-page: None Author: Cyclic3 Author-email: cyclic3.git@gmail.com License: None Location: /home/USER/.local/lib/python3.8/site-packages Requires: Required-by: ciphey Name: cipheydists Version: 0.3.19 Summary: A collection of distributions, character sets and dictionaries for use in ciphey Home-page: None Author: Cyclic3 Author-email: cyclic3.git@gmail.com License: None Location: /home/USER/.local/lib/python3.8/site-packages Requires: Required-by: ciphey
Additional context Thanks for providing such a great tool. Please fix the issue and make it better. Looking forward to using it in the future.

comments.comment: Issue-Label Bot is automatically applying the label bug to this issue, with a confidence of 0.90. Please mark this comment with üëç or üëé to give our bot feedback! Links: <denchmark-link:https://github.com/marketplace/issue-label-bot>app homepage</denchmark-link> , <denchmark-link:https://mlbot.net/data/Ciphey/Ciphey>dashboard</denchmark-link> and <denchmark-link:https://github.com/hamelsmu/MLapp>code</denchmark-link> for this bot.

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/lukasgabriel>@lukasgabriel</denchmark-link>
I've put up <denchmark-link:https://github.com/Ciphey/Ciphey/pull/293>a pull request</denchmark-link> to add @DarshanBhoi!

As discussed in the discord, this is sort of intended behaviour, since this is clearly not standard english text, a flag, or JSON. The checks that prevent this from being decoded can be bypassed with this (assuming you have a crib of squad): <denchmark-code>ciphey -t "Ecgudfxq_EcGmP" -p caesar.p_value=-1 -C regex -p regex.regex=(?i)squad </denchmark-code>
To break this rather cryptic command down:
Flags Description
-t "Ecgudfxq_EcGmP" Your ciphertext
-p caesar.p_value=-1 Allows any casear candidates that have more than a -100% chance to be used (i.e. all of them)
-C regex -p regex.regex=(?i)squad Use the regex checker with the crib squad. The (?i) is a python regex flag that means to use a case-insensitive search
On closer inspection, it appears that this is actually a symptom of #291. This may work after that is fixed Edit: It's not to do with casing

I am closing this issue because it's solved. Currently running ciphey -t "Ecgudfxq_EcGmP" works for me, without using regex. It gets decrypted by the Affine cracker (this is because Affine with a = 1 is the equivalent of a Caesar cipher) and then the underscore gets converted to a space by the leetspeak decoder.
